"SINGAPORE FREE PRESS"
(Statement by the Chief Minister)


    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): May it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, I consider it my duty to bring to your notice conduct which you may consider a breach of the liberties and privileges of this House. I produce, Sir, a copy of a newspaper called the Singapore Free Press of Friday, the 22nd of July.

    I draw attention to the headline - "ROYAL MESSAGE ATTACKED"- and to the first paragraph wherein parts of my speech were so juxtaposed as to give a completely distorted picture of what was, in fact, said and intended.

    We in this House are entitled to freedom from malicious distortion in any report of our proceedings. I would add, Sir, that this malicious report did, in fact, produce to some extent what may have been the intended result. I

Column: 465

understand that certain jelly-fish on the Committee of the Straits Chinese British Association capable of reading headlines began quaking and emitting noxious substances as frightened jellyfish are wont to do.

    Sir, if there had been anything said which reflected on Her Majesty, whether intentional or otherwise, I have not the slightest doubt - nor has any Member of this House - that you would promptly have named the Member responsible, be he the Chief Minister or any other person. But, even assuming that it is possible, Mr Speaker, that in the rapidity of debate you may not have noticed any slighting reference, however unintentional, I do ask, with respect, that you look at the Hansard, the Official Report of the Proceedings of this House, and that you take such steps to clarify the position, either towards me or towards the paper in question, as you may deem fit. And I think it only proper to add, Sir, that I personally resent very strongly the suggestion that I should be capable of discourtesy to Her Majesty.

    Issue of the Singapore Free Press in question handed in.

    Mr Speaker: I will look into the matter, Mr Chief Minister.

SINGAPORE COLONY ORDER IN COUNCIL, 1955
(INTERPRETATION)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question - [22nd July]:

    That the Speaker do convey to His Excellency the Governor the view of this House that the people of Singapore are determined to end colonialism and to rule themselves through their elected representatives;

    And that as a demonstration of the good faith of Her Majesty's Government in its oft-repeated promise to the people of Malaya that they would grant self-government at the earliest possible moment, the most liberal construction legally permissible in favour of the elected representatives of the people in the interpretation of the Singapore Colony Order in Council, 1955, should be adopted;

    And that where the Governor is required by the provisions of the said Order in Council to consult with the Chief Minister before taking any action, he should act in accordance with such advice;

    And that the Speaker do report back to this House on the reply he receives from His Excellency the Governor to this message, and

Column: 466

that thereafter this Assembly do take such action on motions without notice as the circumstances may require.

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Tan Theng Chiang (Rochore): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion standing in the name of the Hon. the Chief Minister. It is indeed tragic that a constitutional crisis should have arisen so early in the life of the present Government. Some people say that the crisis was brought about by my Party's desire to patch up the differences within our Party by offering jobs as Assistant Ministers to Members of the Party. Nothing is further from the truth - that there is any split in the Party. It is only natural for our opponents to fabricate stories and impute sinister motives towards us -

    Mr Speaker: I have already overruled any reference to the merits or demerits of the appointment of Assistant Ministers. Will the Member for Rochore please keep away from it?

    Mr Tan Theng Chiang: This is the first time in the history of Singapore that elected representatives of the people have been called to shoulder the responsibilities of government, and we do not claim that our Party is overflowing with talent and sufficiently experienced to shoulder such responsibilities. It is therefore necessary that if we are to achieve self-government within a set time-limit, as many persons as possible in the early stages should be afforded the opportunity to acquire experience and knowledge which would enable them to run the government independently in time to come. However, I would observe that to make the Rendel Constitution workable and to prove the sincerity of Her Majesty's Government in its oft-repeated assurance that we would be given self-government, the constitution should be interpreted as liberally as possible, and it should also be made as flexible as possible. Above all, there should be a spirit of compromise in the event of any difference of opinion arising between the Governor and the Council of Ministers. It is therefore unfortunate that His Excellency should have adopted an adamant attitude on such a minor issue as

Column: 467

the appointment of junior Ministers, and precipitated a constitutional crisis. It is of paramount importance that we should make it clear once and for all as to who governs this country - that is, the Governor or the elected representatives of the people. It will be meaningless to claim that it is the people's representatives who govern, if their advice is rejected and their efforts thwarted.

    I am glad that this controversy has at least one good effect. It has made the colonial Government come out of its shell and to admit publicly that it was not their intention to grant rapid self-government to the people of Singapore. This has exposed their hypocrisy. Self-government is one of the main platforms of every political Party, not only in Singapore, but also in every colonial territory in the British Empire. However, it is our Party, and our Party alone, which had the courage and foresight to announce that it was our intention to achieve self-government within four years. If we hope for self-government without fixing a definite date for achieving same, it would be tantamount to hoping for the moon. We cannot achieve anything, either in our personal ambitions or in politics, unless we fix our goal and work according to schedule.

    While vested interests are happy over the Governor's statement in this respect, the man-in-the-street is doubting whether Her Majesty's Government are genuine in their promise to grant us self-government. If we are wrong in hoping for self-government within four years, let them tell us, in no unmistaken terms, when we would be granted independence.

    In the Twentieth Century no civilised nation would like the idea if being subjected to another, and I ask for a clear-cut statement on this point. I am amazed to hear from my hon. Friend Mr Sutherland that there are thousands of Asians in this island who have little to complain of under colonial rule. It shows the narrowness of his sphere of acquaintance. Being an expatriate himself and a representative of the vested interests in the bargain, he cannot be expected to, and would not climb down

Column: 468

from his pedestal and mix up with the man-in-the-street to obtain his views on the issue.

    I, for one, would grant that we owe a lot to the colonial power in the same way as we are grateful to the pioneering Chinese and Indians who, through their sweat and toil, built up the prosperity of Singapore and Malaya. We are not hostile towards the British, and there is no reason why we should not continue on friendly terms with them even after we have gained our self-government or independence. Colonialism has had its usefulness, but the time has come when we must demand what is our birthright - the right to govern ourselves.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, in all territories under the jurisdiction of the United Kingdom Government, Britain holds the responsibility for answering to the United Nations and the world at large for their affairs and administration. That is the reason why in the constitution of every British non-self-governing territory the final say in the administration is vested with the Governor.

    If you examine the constitution of Singapore and even more advanced territories like the Gold Coast, you will find that, wherever it is provided that the Governor, before taking any action, should consult a Minister, or even the whole Council of Ministers, the final say rests with the Governor. It is only when there is a transfer of power granting independence to any hitherto dependent territory that you find this reserved power of the Governor eliminated.

    The Progressive Party has already made it quite clear that it is in full agreement with the first and second parts of this motion. The third part seeks to place an interpretation which will have the effect of removing some of the Governor's powers and of having the final say in the administration of this country. If such powers are, in fact, to be taken from the Governor, then we shall have the position of the British Government remaining responsible and answerable to the world at large for the affairs of this country, and at the same time deprived of the power of being the

Column: 469

ultimate authority over some administrative matters. It is therefore logical that if we demand such powers, then we must be prepared to shoulder all consequential responsibilities.

    From the tone in which this debate has been carried on, it is obvious that many, in fact the majority of the Members of this House, are of the view that we should now demand that whenever the Governor should consult the Chief Minister, and a fortiori the Council of Ministers, the Governor should not have the final say. That being the case, let us be honest about it. Let us not ask for these very far-reaching powers without having to shoulder the resulting responsibilities. The demand for these far-reaching powers without the consequential changes in the constitution would result in our having the powers while Britain retains the liabilities. Let us therefore play the game, and ask for a full transfer of power so that we, and we alone, shall be responsible for our own affairs and destiny and the British Government need no longer be answerable for us.

    In accordance with the principles which I have stated, I therefore move an amendment, which will not only be in line with the first and second parts of this motion, but also remove all future occasions for dissatisfaction. I therefore move that the motion be amended by adding the following new part between parts three and four of the motion:

    "And that in the opinion of this House the time has arrived for a transfer of power from the Government of the United Kingdom to the people of Singapore, and that a new constitution providing for independence should he granted immediately."

    Mr Speaker: May I have that in writing, please?

    Amendment handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The amendment is in order.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to second this amendment.

    The Chief Minister: Once upon a time, Mr Speaker, Sir, not very long ago, the Progressive Party during the elections, hoping to attract the votes of the Queen's

Column: 470

Chinese, and some others, said they were against multi-lingualism. In this House we had the horrible spectacle, Sir, very soon after we sat, of seeing them perform political somersaults -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chief Minister -

    The Chief Minister: I apologise , Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Can I remind you. Mr Chief Minister, of our Standing Orders? There must not be any offensive or insulting language about Members of the Assembly.

    The Chief Minister: With respect, Mr Speaker, Sir, the Progressive Party consists of many parts, of which only the rump is in the Assembly!

    On Friday, Sir, we had the spectacle of the existing Members in this Assembly of the Progressive Party complaining bitterly that some power would be taken from the Governor and given to the people's chief elected representative. Today, in order to make a farce of a solemn motion, of one that answers our deep needs, we have an amendment - an amendment which, it is suggested, would be politically impossible for anyone to resist. I am not a politician. I could not survive even one year in the Progressive Party. But I am not afraid of taking honest decisions, whatever the political consequences. Independence today is an impossibility, and may I say, Sir, with respect to the Standing Orders, that the amendment is made by the hon. Gentleman with his tongue in his cheek! We have the Federation of Malaya to consider. We seem to have forgotten it, as in its hustings it seems to have forgotten us. We are not playing a game of marbles: children in a dirty back-alley. We are supposed to be men of responsibility, answerable for the welfare of more than a million people, not political manoeuvres. In these circumstances, Sir, I welcome this further disclosure of the traditional conduct of the Progressive Party, and I move this amendment to the amendment - that for the word 'independence' the word 'self-government' be substituted, and that we do ask for a transfer of power, for self-government immediately. I beg to move.

    Mr Speaker: May I have that in writing, please, Mr Chief Minister?

    Amendment handed in.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I should be only too happy to support the amendment put forward by the Member for Paya Lebar (Mr Lim Koon Teck if I thought it was practicable. But, in my opinion, it is impossible to suggest that we are ready for complete independence today. We may be ready in just a few years' time.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chief Minister, your amendment is in order.

    The Minister for Labour and Welfare (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to second the amendment to the amendment.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, we are constantly being astonished by the versatility of our friends on my side of the House. I find it almost incredible that a man could come here a week ago and say that we are incapable, we are not fit to tell Her Majesty's Government that her representative should accept the advice of the Chief Minister of this Colony, and on the Monday, after the picture has become a little bit clearer -

    Mr Speaker: Order, please. We are now on the amendment to the amendment. We are talking of self-government as against independence.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Indeed, Mr Speaker, Sir -

    Mr Speaker: Order, please. The Member for Tanjong Pagar will have the opportunity of speaking, as he wishes to speak, when the original amendment is put to the House. Now we are concerned with whether or not the word "self-government" should be inserted in the place of "independence". As I understand it, the mover of the original amendment has accepted that amendment to the amendment.

    Question, "That the word 'independence' proposed to be left out, be left out of the Original Amendment, and the word 'self-government' proposed to be inserted, be there inserted," put, and agreed to.

    Original amendment, as amended, again proposed.

    The Assistant Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, Sir, before the Member for Paya Lebar moved the amendment just now, he was bewailing and bemoaning the fact that certain powers of His Excel1ency the Governor were going to be taken away and transferred to the representatives of the people. Sir, just after he finished that sentence, he came out with an amendment which sought to give us complete independence; and before one minute had expired, he accepted another amendment to the effect that we wanted self-government.

    Now, Sir, self-government and independence are poles apart. This shows the political acrobatics of those who sit in that corner of the House -

    Mr Speaker: I must rule the Minister out of order. Will he please withdraw the word "acrobatics"?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: I withdraw it. Sir.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, we would all rejoice if, for one moment, we could believe that these gentlemen believe in what they are today proposing sincerely and not as a piece of political chicanery.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Lee Kuan Yew, I should like to put this debate on a proper plane. Let us have this debate on a high plane. Let us not come down to personalities. You are offending Standing Order No. 31 (6), which says that no Member shall impute improper motives to any other Member. Remember, hon. Gentlemen, that what you say outside this Assembly cannot necessarily be said in this Assembly because of our Standing Orders.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir. I seldom indulge in what you refer to as personal attacks. My attack on them is not one on their personal merits as Assemblymen or as good fathers and good sons and loving husbands. My attack on them is for the hypocrisy of this move, that, in my opinion -

Column: 473



    Mr Speaker: I will not have unparliamentary language in this Assembly. I have said that before. Please continue.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: If the word "hypocrisy", Mr Speaker, Sir, is unparliamentary, may I put it this way? I find it extremely difficult to imagine that within the space of three days a Party, which has stood against more power being given to the Chief Minister, could, in all sincerity, come and say that they would wish Her Majesty's Government to transfer all the Governor's powers to the Chief Minister and his colleagues.

    The Chief Minister has said that he is not a politician. Sir, if he were, he would not have accepted this amendment. He would have let it go on the original motion as it stood, for having moved an amendment to minimise the original motion, they would have given us the singular privilege of seeing them vote for that motion. There were three things they could have done on that original motion - either vote for; vote against; or abstain. They could hardly have voted for, because they have moved an amendment.

    Sir, now we have the most astonishing spectacle of seeing the Progressive Party being the fiercest Party of us all! They are the people, the Member for Paya Lebar has said it bold and clear, whose cry is "We want independence now!" When the People's Action Party said these things, the world trembled because they thought that if these people got in, then they would do what they said they were going to do. But when the Member for Paya Lebar said it, I can quite imagine the hon. Mr Sutherland being quite unmoved.

    Sir, we will have to accept this amendment because the Chief Minister has moved it. If he had not been such a political innocent, he would have forced this issue as it stood and we would have had the privilege of seeing the four Progressive gentlemen vote against that motion, if they had the courage; or abstain, if they had not the courage. Be that as it may, they hope - it is still not certain yet - that they can go back to the

Column: 474

country and say, "We went to the Assembly and we said to the Chief Secretary (Mr Goode) that we wanted independence now. And then the Chief Minister, who is a timorous man, said he only wanted self-government. But the Progressive Party believes in independence. It believes in it fearlessly!"

    Sir, it is a topic on which I think the People's Action Party is on much more familiar ground. If it is of any assistance to the Member for Paya Lebar, I could give him some of the scripts of the People's Action Party's views in the past on this topic of independence. I think he would make a much more convincing case if he were to crib some of the passages from our Party manifesto and our election platform. The Progressive Party was the one which went before the electorate and said, "We believe" - (the Straits Times gave it tremendous prominence, and I am sure it must have pleased Mr Sutherland very much) - "in slow, orderly peaceful government. We are against all this haste and all this wild talk by irresponsible people of this country for independence." Today we are entertained by the unique spectacle of the mouse turned lion.

    Question,

    "That a new part be inserted between the third and fourth parts of the Original Question, "And that in the opinion of this House the time has arrived for a transfer of power from the Government of the United Kingdom to the people of Singapore, and that a new constitution providing for self-government should be granted immediately;",

put, and agreed to.

    Main Question, as amended, again proposed.

    The Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Francis Thomas): As the debate developed, Mr Speaker, Sir, on Friday, and as it has developed indeed this morning, we have had a certain amount of Party rancour and even manoeuvre from some of the Opposition Members, which has had, in fact, the happy result of producing an amendment to this motion which has just been accepted, and this has left us

Column: 475

pretty well where we were before. The Progressive Party are anxious to attach a name to what would already have been the substance in any case. What do they mean by "immediately" I do not know. I presume they do not expect a new constitution to be written tonight and published tomorrow, but they will no doubt accept that "immediately" means "as soon as possible".

    Now, I hope that we have, with this last amendment, reached the end of the party strife and manoeuvre, because this is a matter which should rise far above personal and party feelings. As the Chief Minister opened the debate on Friday, he informed the Opposition that the Party Whip had been withdrawn, and he invited all Members to speak and to vote in accordance with their innermost convictions. I hope that from now on all will do so. I hope all have done so so far. But although the Chief Minister did his best to secure that we should be free from party strife, there were and there have been a number of bitter words, imputations and recriminations, which have compelled you, Mr Speaker, to intervene and to remind us continually of the Standing Orders. Members have gone beyond what is permissible in this chaste Assembly, and as a result there has been some confusion of the constitutional issue. I wish to stress again that the importance of this constitutional issue lies finally in the fact that we are all substantially agreed on it. If there was real disagreement in this House, the issue would be dead, or at least would have to be kept in cold storage until you could get substantial unanimity in the people and in their representatives. But since all are agreed, then we should all speak and vote in unity; vote loyally to give effect to the wishes of the people; give effect to our own innermost convictions. But to try to reap party advantage on this occasion, to give vent to personal ill-feeling, bears the appearance of indescribable small-mindedness. Tomorrow there will be a proper and full opportunity for all the bitterness, the party strife, the rancour, the manoeuvres, the imputations, the

Column: 476

misrepresentations, in which some Members are happy to indulge. But today can we not all join to put forward together the cause of freedom, the cause of self-government, on which we all agree? And if today is no time for party bitterness, I suggest that it is also no time for expressing bitterness against the Imperial power, or against the representatives of the Imperial power in this territory.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: This sounds like moral rearmament!

    Mr Francis Thomas: It is rather more practical than moral rearmament. We have in the world today three major world groupings. You have, to the north of us, what the geo-politicians call the "heart-land", which is controlled by the Communists - Russia, China and their dependencies and subordinate bodies. You have, across the Pacific, the United States of America with its dependencies and its dollar diplomacy; and you have, away on the west of us, the United Kingdom and around us the Commonwealth of Nations. And as the world is today, no small territory can stand alone. We are a small territory. We shall still be small when we have achieved union with the Federation. We cannot stand alone. We shall have to associate ourselves with one of these major world groupings. And if a choice has to be made, there is no doubt in my mind that the choice should fall on the Commonwealth of Nations. I say this without prejudice to what I hope we shall achieve in the future - which is a fourth major world grouping, which would extend from the Himalayas to the South Pacific, to include so many new and free nations and peoples, and which we hope could rise above the greeds and jealousies, rivalries, disputes and war and folly, which have disgraced the history of the great Powers in the past. But that is over the horizon of the future still, and for the time being this territory will have no choice but to go with one of the three major world groupings that I have named. It appears to me that all the advantage to us will lie in retaining

Column: 477

in some form our present association. So I shall refrain from wounding words and from bitterness, and perhaps I might take this opportunity, Mr Speaker, Sir - and here I am sure I shall not transgress Standing Orders - in expressing my personal feelings, my deep sense of the most fulsome compliment which was paid by the Member for Telok Ayer (Mr R. Jumabhoy) when he was speaking about the Chief Minister. I know that he was pulled up for improper language in parts of his speech, but nevertheless he did describe the Chief Minister as a bee, a honey bee, and I thought it was a most appropriate comparison to make -

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: On a point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir. Is it necessary to make references now on this?

    The Chief Minister: Why, does it hurt you? [Interruption.]

    Mr Speaker: Order, please. The hon. Member is perfectly entitled to make his speech. If he is irrelevant, I will pull him up. Mr Thomas.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I am sorry that the Member for Telok Ayer is not happy with my enlarging on his metaphor, but I would like to complete it. In comparing the Chief Minister to a bee, I felt it was most appropriate because the bee is such an energetic fellow. With incessant energy he continues to accumulate honey, not for himself but for the service of others. Moreover, the bee is, when attacked, armed with a sting with which he can do damage!

    Now, on Friday, the Chief Minister argued - and I felt with very great force and cogency - that in the relevant section of the constitutional document the word "may" is directive and not permissive. This point seems to present some difficulty, perhaps, to some Members of this House, and certainly elsewhere, and if people are unconvinced, I would suggest that, for the purposes of argument, I shall pass by the Chief Minister's array of legal authorities, his picul or so of calf-bound tomes which he brought with him in case they were needed, and I will grant, purely

Column: 478

for purposes of argument, that in this matter His Excellency has certain discretionary powers. I will proceed to examine what is then the position if those powers, in fact, are rightly in His Excellency's control.

    I will quote as my first authority Professor Barriedale Keith. His textbook - the British Cabinet System - is, I believe, a reasonable work of reference which is accepted as an authority. He points out that when a British Colony adopts the British Cabinet system - as we are doing here - it necessarily adopts also the fundamental principles and practice of the British Cabinet system. And so, if we can accept Professor Keith as being right - and obviously he must be because you cannot adopt a model of democracy without adopting the principles which have produced that model - if he is right, we have to examine the principles on which we are hoping to proceed. Our attention has been very much fixed on one major principle, which is that the Sovereign, or in this territory the Sovereign's representative, should act on the advice of his Ministers when it is formally and officially tendered to him through the Chief Minister. That principle, I think, is clear to everybody, and nobody has any difficulty or doubt about the statement of the principle. Where the difficulty and doubt has come, at least in His Excellency's mind, is whether that principle should be applied here and now. My object is to show that it can and should be applied, without hesitation and without delay.

    I will quote, in support of that, another principle which is equally fundamental and perhaps more far-reaching: a principle which can best be stated by saying that the constitution must be flexible. It must have flexibility and the possibility of adaptation to things as they change. In Britain, there is no written constitution. You have various fixed constitutional points such as Magna Carta or the Bill of Rights, or the Parliament Act of 1911, or the Habeas Corpus Act, which can be called constitutional documents, but they do not amount to a written constitution. In

Column: 479

so far as they have any effect, their effect is to give more freedom and more liberty of action. They do not restrict people in any way, except to restrict the power of the Executive to some extent.

    The Commonwealth of Nations also has no written constitution. The whole British system is based on the fact that you deal with situations as they arise, and you do not tie yourself down in writing to an intention which you cannot, in fact, carry out because the situation has changed.

    You do have in the United States of America a written constitution, and they get into quite a mess with it sometimes. My little reading in American history has indicated that they get conflicting interpretations according to the political colour of the country at different times. There is a fairly long time lag between changes, and certainly in Singapore we have already got into some difficulty with our written constitution. It is precisely because we have a written constitution that we need this principle of flexibility. It was inevitable that we should have a constitution written, because whilst elsewhere constitutions have grown up slowly over a long period of time, here no opportunity for constitutional progress was made. If progress had started 50 years ago, we should now no doubt have conventions instead of a written constitution, but we have not. We have to cram into a few years the progress that might well have been spread over half a century.

    And so I pass to my next authority. This is no massive tome, but I received it some two or three months ago from our worthy friend the Public Relations Officer. It is published by the Central Office of Information. The title is The Monarchy and The Commonwealth, and it says on the inside cover that this document is intended as reference material and is derived from authoritative sources and may be freely used in preparing articles, speeches, broadcasts, etc. I take it that it is authoritative, because it comes from an authoritative source, and I take it as being a reasonable and fair statement of what the British position is.

Column: 480



    "Constitutional conventions differ from strict law in that they are not recognised and applied by the Courts" - I know that some Members of this House wish them to be brought to the Courts, but they did not appreciate the British approach to constitutional problems. They are not recognised and applied by the Courts - "but nevertheless they are indispensable and lend themselves to adaptation to changing conditions without serious disturbance to existing legislative forms. It was largely by means of the firm establishment of such conventions that in the course of centuries restrictions were imposed on the use of the Royal prerogative and that the powers of the Crown, ceasing to be at the personal disposal of the Sovereign" - or in Singapore the Sovereign's representative - "came to be the means of giving effect to the wishes of the people". I will repeat the two key portions of that quotation - "adaptation to changing conditions without serious disturbance to existing legislative forms". We have changing conditions. They have changed rapidly. We do need to be able to adapt to them. The Progressive Party has now made it necessary, through their amendment, that we should disturb the existing legislative forms.
